diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: Kawasaki Disease is a rare condition that mainly affects children under the age of 5. It's characterized by inflammation of blood vessels throughout the body and can lead to coronary artery aneurysms. Key features include fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, redness in the eyes, lips, and throat, along with peeling skin on the hands and feet weeks after the fever starts.

diagnoses.name: Streptococcal Pharyngitis
diagnoses.description: Streptococcal Pharyngitis, caused by Group A Streptococcus bacteria, presents with sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. It may sometimes be associated with skin rash and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Infectious Mononucleosis, often caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, presents with fatigue, sore throat, fever, swollen lymph nodes, and occasionally spleen enlargement. It can affect the liver and lead to mild hepatitis.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: Scarlet Fever is caused by an infection with a Group A Streptococcus bacteria that produces a toxin, leading to a distinctive rash, sore throat, fever, and strawberry-like appearance of the tongue. It often presents with a fine, sandpaper-like rash and red flush around the face.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: Reactive Arthritis is a condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body, often presenting with joint pain, inflammation, and swelling. It can sometimes manifest with conjunctivitis and urethritis.

diagnoses.name: Acute Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.description: This condition follows infection with certain strains of Group A Streptococcus, leading to glomerulonephritis, manifested by hematuria, proteinuria, and hypertension. It represents the body's immune response damaging the kidney's filtering units.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura is a type of vasculitis causing purple spots on the skin, joint pain, abdominal pain, and kidney involvement. It's commonly seen in children following an upper respiratory tract infection.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
diagnoses.description: DRESS syndrome is a severe, drug-induced reaction characterized by widespread skin rash, fever, lymph node enlargement, hepatitis, and involvement of other organs. It involves eosinophilia and systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Toxic Shock Syndrome is a rare, life-threatening complication of certain bacterial infections, often associated with tampon use, skin wounds, or surgery. It's characterized by sudden high fever, rash, low blood pressure, and sometimes peeling skin.

diagnoses.name: Gonococcal Arthritis
diagnoses.description: Gonococcal Arthritis is a complication of gonorrhea, manifesting as a painful joint condition due to the spread of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. It can lead to dermatitis and tenosynovitis apart from arthritis.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Schizophreniform Disorder (in the context of CNS infection)

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: A disease that can affect the heart, joints, brain, and skin, which can develop after a strep throat or scarlet fever infection that is not properly treated.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include fever, headache, and fatigue, often with a skin rash called erythema migrans.

diagnoses.name: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A term used to describe a group of disorders in children that includes arthritis lasting for at least six weeks and that starts before the age of 16.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue in many parts of the body–symptoms vary between people and may be mild to severe.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body (cross-reactivity). It primarily affects the joints, but can also affect the eyes, skin, and urethra.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. The immune system mistakenly attacks the body's tissues, causing painful swelling.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory type of arthritis that occurs in some patients with psoriasis. This condition can affect any part of the body, including the hands, feet, spine, eyes, and nails.

diagnoses.name: Adult-Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis that features fevers, rash and joint pain. Some people have a single episode of signs and symptoms while others experience many episodes or persistent symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: A viral infection causing fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph glands, especially in the neck. It is typically caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. In people with sarcoidosis, abnormal masses or nodules called granulomas consisting of inflamed tissues form in certain organs of the body.

diagnoses: Kidney disease related to lupus (lupus nephritis)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., Viral or Bacterial infections leading to reactive arthritis and pericarditis)
Acute Glomerulonephritis (with nephrotic or nephritic syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhoids
diagnoses.description: Swollen and inflamed veins in the rectum and anus that cause discomfort and bleeding. Hemorrhoids are associated with chronic constipation, straining, and aging.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from too little iron in the body, which is necessary for making red blood cells. This condition can lead to episodic weakness and may be related to gastrointestinal bleeding caused by hemorrhoids.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can lead to anemia, causing weakness and fatigue. It can also cause neurological problems, including physical sensitivities and dysgeusia (changes in taste perception).

diagnoses.name: Fabry Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that disrupts the body's ability to break down specific fatty substances. Symptoms can include episodic weakness, angiokeratoma (which could be similar in appearance to angiomata), and gastrointestinal symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects blood vessels and can cause bleeding, anemia (leading to weakness), and small red to purple spots often referred to as telangiectases or angiomata.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of zinc can lead to dysgeusia, weakened immune response, and might exacerbate or be linked to the presence of hemorrhoids due to impaired wound healing.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause episodic weakness, sensitivity to touch, and dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes tumors to form on nerve tissue. These tumors are usually benign but can lead to a range of symptoms, including the development of angiomata-like skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A result of damage to the peripheral nerves, often causing weakness, numbness and pain, usually in the hands and feet. It may also cause hypersensitivity to physical stimuli.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough crucial hormones, leading to fatigue, weakness, and potentially contributing to the development of dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Myeloproliferative disorders
diagnoses.description: Group of diseases of the blood and bone marrow where excess cells are produced.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells.

diagnoses.name: Essential thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A chronic blood disorder characterized by the overproduction of platelets in the bone marrow.

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.description: Anemia caused by a lack of iron, leading to a reduced production of hemoglobin. Iron deficiency can sometimes lead to increased platelet counts.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory disorders
diagnoses.description: Diseases characterized by inflammation, such as rheumatoid arthritis or lupus, which can affect multiple systems including the heart and eyes.

diagnoses.name: Infections
diagnoses.description: Various infections can cause elevated platelet counts and affect the heart rhythm or eye health.

diagnoses.name: Chronic myeloid leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and blood, leading to an overproduction of white cells.

diagnoses.name: Allergic conjunctivitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction affecting the eyes, causing irritation and redness.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune disorders
diagnoses.description: Diseases where the body's immune system attacks its own tissues, potentially affecting multiple organs including the eyes and ear (otitis externa).

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: Lack of water in the body can cause thickened blood, potentially leading to thrombocytosis, and can impact cardiovascular and renal function.

dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Viral infections (such as norovirus or rotavirus)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.comments: Migraines can present with photophobia, phonophobia, and, in the case of visual migraines, scotoma. However, hearing loss is not typically a symptom.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.comments: Symptoms can include diplopia and scotoma due to optic neuritis, as well as other neurological symptoms. Hearing loss is rare in MS.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.comments: Primarily causing hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo. Photophobia and phonophobia can occur during vertigo episodes. Diplopia and scotoma are not typical symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.comments: Depending on its location, a brain tumor could cause a combination of these symptoms, especially if it affects the auditory or optic nerves or pathways.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.comments: In its later stages, can cause neurological problems including facial palsy leading to diplopia, as well as hearing problems. Photophobia and phonophobia might also occur.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Schwannoma (Acoustic Neuroma)
diagnoses.comments: This benign tumor primarily causes hearing loss and tinnitus. Other symptoms like diplopia may occur if the tumor compresses surrounding nerves.

diagnoses.name: Arnold-Chiari Malformation
diagnoses.comments: This condition can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including those listed, due to the effects on the cerebellum and brain stem.

diagnoses.name: Migrainous Stroke
diagnoses.comments: A rare form of stroke linked to migraine, particularly with aura, which can cause a wide array of neurological symptoms including visual disturbances like scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.comments: Can affect the nervous system (neurosarcoidosis), leading to cranial neuropathies. This might present as diplopia, hearing loss, or other sensory deficits.

diagnoses.name: Otosclerosis
diagnoses.comments: Primarily affecting hearing, this condition typically wouldn't cause the other symptoms directly but could occur alongside other conditions.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is often accompanied by visual disturbances (scintillation) and sensory symptoms (parasthesia, weakness). Vertigo can also be a symptom.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to symptoms like weakness, parasthesia, and in some cases, vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it can cause sudden weakness, parasthesia, and other transient neurological deficits such as visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A cerebrovascular accident that can cause sudden weakness, numbness (parasthesia), visual problems, and sometimes vertigo, depending on the area of the brain affected.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Migraine
diagnoses.description: A variant of migraine where the predominant symptom is vertigo, often accompanied by migrainous symptoms like scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the nerve that connects the ear to the brain, leading to hearing loss, vertigo, and sometimes parasthesia of the face.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, including symptoms like parasthesia and occasionally visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing severe vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes a feeling of fullness or pressure in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Depending on its location, a brain tumor can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms, including weakness, parasthesia, vertigo, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes, leading to weakness, parasthesia, and occasionally, vestibular dysfunction causing vertigo.

diagnoses: Toxic Effects of Medications or Substances
Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia combined with immune thrombocytopenia)
Infections causing reactive arthritis (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus, HIV)
Lupus Panniculitis (also known as Lupus Profundus)
Hepatitis B and C related glomerulonephritis
Chilblains lupus (a subtype of lupus erythematosus)
Viral infections (certain types, such as coxsackievirus or parvovirus B19)
